questions.text: Which is the best sample for DNA fingerprinting in a fresh dead body?
questions.solution:
• Best sample for fingerprint both in living and dead is blood in EDTA tube.
  • If decomposition is established, muscle or spleen are used.
  • In cases of advance decomposition, bone marrow and teeth are used.

Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Gautama Biswas-5th edition; pg:485

choices.text: Death of a prisoner in the jail

questions.text: A Magistrate conducts an inquest, instead of or in addition to the police inquest in which of the following condition?
questions.solution:
A Magistrate may conduct an inquest in case of –

  • Death in police custody, and while under police interrogation.
  • Death due to police firing.
  • Death in prison, reformatories, borstal school.
  • Death in a psychiatric hospital.
  • Dowry deaths.
  • Any person dies or disappears, or rape is alleged to have been committed on any woman, while such person or woman is in the custody of the police or in any other custody authorised by the court. (S.174(4), S.176 and 176, 1-A, Cr.P.C.).

In any case of death, a Magistrate may conduct an inquest, instead of or in addition to the police inquest (S.176, Cr.P.C.).

Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Gautam Biswas-5th edition: pg-6-7

questions.text: Punishment for a murder will be awarded by which court of law in India?
questions.solution:
• The Sessions Court is established by the State Government (S.9, Cr.P.C.) and is usually located at the district headquarters. It can only try cases which have been committed to it by a Magistrate (S.l93, Cr.P.C.). It can pass any sentence authorised by law, but a sentence of death passed by it must be confirmed by the High Court (S.28 (2) and S. 366, Cr.P.C.).
  • An Assistant Sessions Court can pass a sentence of imprisonment up to ten years and unlimited fine (S.28 (3), Cr.P.C.).
  • The Chief Judicial Magistrate can pass a sentence of imprisonment up to 7 years and unlimited fine. In metropolitan cities with more than 1 million population, the Chief Judicial Magistrate is designated as Metropolitan Magistrate.

Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Gautam Biswas-5th edition; pg:7-9

choices.text: Compos mentis should be certified before recording dying declaration
Leading question can be allowed during recording dying declaration
If declarant survives, the declaration has no value in court of law
Oath is administered before recording dying declaration

questions.text: Which of the following statement/s are true regarding the dying declaration?
questions.solution:
DYING DECLARATION:

  • It is a written or oral statement of a person, who is dying as a result of some unlawful act, relating to the material facts of cause of his death or bearing on the circumstances (32, I.E.A.).
  • If there is time, the Executive magistrate should be called to record the declaration.
  • Before recording the statement, the doctor should certify that the person is conscious and his mental faculties are normal (compos mentis).
  • While recording the dying declaration, oath is not administered, because of the belief that the dying person tells the truth.
  • The statement should be recorded in the man's own words, without any alteration of terms or phrases. Leading questions should not be put.
  • If the declarant survives, the declaration is not admitted, but has corroborative value, and the person is called to give oral evidence.

Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Gautam Biswas-5th edition; pg:10-12

choices.text: Sexual intercourse with patient/ relative of the patient
Not displaying Registration number of Medical council
Disclosing HIV positive status to the partner of a person

questions.text: A 'Warning notice' is issued by the medical council in all of the following conditions, except
questions.solution:
According to Sec.9 of The HIV And AIDS Prevention And Control Act, 2017,

Disclosure of HIV-positive status to the partner of a HIV-positive person.

  • No healthcare provider, except a physician or a counsellor, shall disclose the HIV-positive status of a person to his or her partner.
  • A healthcare provider, who is a physician or counsellor, may disclose the HIV-positive status of a person under his direct care to his or her partner, if such healthcare provider—
    • Reasonably believes that the partner is at the significant risk of transmission of HIV from such person; and
    • Such HIV-positive person has been counselled to inform such partner; and
    • Is satisfied that the HIV-positive person will not inform such partner; and
    • Has informed the HIV-positive person of the intention to disclose the HIV positive status to such partner.
    • Provided that disclosure under this subsection to the partner shall be made in person after counselling.
    • Provided further that such healthcare provider shall have no obligation to identify or locate the partner of an HIV-positive person.
    • Provided also that such healthcare provider shall not inform the partner of a woman where there is a reasonable apprehension that such information may result in violence, abandonment or actions which may have a severe negative effect on the physical or mental health or safety of such woman, her children, her relatives or someone who is close to her.
  • The healthcare provider under sub-section (1) shall not be liable for any criminal or civil action for any disclosure or non-disclosure of confidential HIV-related information made to a partner under this section.

Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Gautam Biswas-5th edition; pg:27-28

questions.text: The Supreme court of India has passed the order allowing which type of Euthanasia in India?
questions.solution:
On 9 March 2018 the Supreme Court of India legalised passive euthanasia by means of the withdrawal of life support to patients in a permanent vegetative state. The decision was made as part of the verdict in a case involving Aruna Shanbaug, who had been in a Persistent Vegetative State (PVS) until her death in 2015.

Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Gautam Biswas-5th edition; pg:43-44

choices.text: Age of Viability is 24 weeks IUL
Ossification centre is present in talus at 24 weeks IUL
Meconium is found in the duodenum

questions.text: Which of the following sentence(s) is/are true regarding age of viability?
questions.solution:
• Age of Viability is 28 weeks IUL for India.
  • Ossification centre is present in talus at the end of seventh months
  • Foetus weighs 700 gm at the end of sixth month of IUL.
  • Meconium is found in the duodenum at the end of fourth month of IUL.

Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Gautam Biswas-5th edition; pg:80-93

questions.text: Singed hair is seen in which of the following case?
questions.solution:
Singed hair is swollen, black, fragile, twisted or curled and has a peculiar odour seen in flame burns case.

Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Gautam Biswas-5th edition; pg:293.

questions.text: Which is the undertaker's fracture?
questions.solution:
The so-called "Undertaker's Fracture" is caused due to the head falling backwards forcibly after death, which tears open one of the intervertebral discs usually around C-6 and C-7, due to which subluxation of the lower cervical spine occurs.

Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Gautam Biswas-5th edition; pg:440-41

choices.text: If the right ventricle contain air, the heart will float in water
Pyrogallol test will be false positive in gas formed due to decomposition

questions.text: Which of the following sentence is false regarding post mortem examination in a suspected case of Air Embolism?
questions.solution:
In air embolism -

  • The head should be opened first and the surface vessels of the brain examined for gas bubbles, which must be prominent and definite, but not segmental breakup of the blood in the vessels with collapsed segments between.
  • Care should be taken to avoid pulling the sternum and ribs to avoid creating negative pressure in the tissues which may result in aspiration of air into vessels.
  • Pyrogallol test:
  • 4 ml of a 2% freshly prepared pyrogallol solution is collected into two 10 ml syringes.
  • To the first syringe four drops of 0.5 M sodium hydroxide solution is added.
  • Gas is aspirated from the right side of the heart.
  • The needle is removed and replaced with a stopper and the syringe shaken.
  • If air (oxygen) is present, the mixture turns brown.
  • In the second syringe some air is introduced and the test repeated as a control. The solution should turn brown.
  • This test helps to differentiate gas present in the heart from gas formed due to decomposition.

 

Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Gautam Biswas-5th edition; pg:126-27.

choices.text: At junction of anterior cerebral & anterior communicating arteries
At junction of middle cerebral & posterior communicating arteries
At junction of posterior cerebral & posterior communicating arteries
At junction of superior cerebellar & Basilar arteries

questions.text: Which is the most common site for berry aneurysms?
questions.solution:
Berry aneurysms usually occur at the junction of vessels, most commonly at the junction of anterior cerebral & anterior communicating arteries of the circle of Willis.

Reference: Basic pathology by Robbins, 10e, page 856

questions.text: Viscera can be preserved in following preservative for the purpose of detection of poison, except
questions.solution:
Preservatives for chemical analysis are:

  • Saturated sodium chloride solution, except in poisoning from corrosive acids (except phenol), alkalis, corrosive sublimate, and aconite.
  • Rectified spirit, except in cases of suspected poisoning by:
  • Alcohol, kerosene
  • Chloroform, ether
  • Chloral hydrate
  • Formic acid
  • Formaldehyde, acetic acid
  • Phenol
  • Phosphorus
  • Paraldehyde, because the organic acids and paraldehyde are soluble in alcohol and the phosphorescence of phosphorus is diminished by alcohol.
  • 10 mg/ml of sodium or potassium fluoride (prevents glycolysis, inhibits enzyme enolase and inhibits bacterial growth), and 3 mg of potassium oxalate (anti-coagulant) should be used for preserving blood. Fluoride should also be added to urine, CSF and vitreous humour if alcohol estimation is required and also to samples for analysis for cocaine, cyanide.

The viscera should not be preserved in formaldehyde because extraction of poison, especially non-volatile organic compounds, becomes difficult.

Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Gautam Biswas-5th edition; pg:128-29.

choices.text: Femur give more accurate results than humerus
Right side of bones are normally measured in the dry state without cartilage
Hepburn osteometric board is commonly used for measurement
The tibia account for 27% of the individual height

questions.text: Which of the following sentences is false regarding the estimation of stature from long bones?
questions.solution:
Femur accounts for 27% of the individual height.

Estimation of stature:

  • Weight-bearing long bones are used for applying formula to estimate the stature.
  • Femur and tibia give more accurate results than humerus or radius.
  • The average stature obtained from a measurement of more than one long bone gives a more accurate result than when calculated for a single bone.
  • Right side bones are normally measured in the dry state without cartilage.
  • A useful rule of thumb is that the humerus is 20%, the tibia 22%, the femur 27%, and the spine 35%, of the individual's height in life.
  • The Hepburn osteometric board modified by Trevor is commonly used.

Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Gautam Biswas-5th edition; pg:93-95

questions.text: Which of the following is not a postmortem change?
questions.solution:
• In case of hanging, if the ligature knot presses on cervical sympathetic chain, the eye on the same side may remain open and its pupil dilated (le facie sympathique). It indicates antemortem hanging.
  • If the eyelids are open for a few hours after death, a film of cell debris and mucus forms two yellow triangles on the sclera at each side of the iris, with base towards the margin of cornea and apex towards medial or lateral canthus of the eye, which become brown and then black called "tache noir" within 3 to 4 hours.
  • Fragmentation or in segmentation (trucking or shunting) of the blood columns (Kevorkian sign) in the retinal vessels appear within minutes after death, and persists for about an hour.

Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Gautam Biswas-5th edition; pg:150,180.

choices.text: It is not a sign of death
It helps in estimating the time of injury
It indicates the posture of the body at the time of death
It may indicate the moving of the body to another position sometime after death

questions.text: Which of the following sentences is false regarding the medico-legal aspect of postmortem lividity?
questions.solution:
Medicolegal importance of postmortem lividity is:

  • It is a sign of death.
  • Its extent helps in estimating the time of death, which is unreliable, because of its variability in its appearance.
  • It indicates the posture of the body at the time of death.
  • It may indicate the moving of the body to another position sometime after death.
  • Sometimes, the colour may indicate the cause of death.

Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Gautam Biswas-5th edition; pg:156.

choices.text: Greenish discoloration of right iliac fossa
Marbling present over roots of the upper limbs
Reddish brown discoloration of inner surface of aorta

questions.text: First external sign of decomposition is
questions.solution:
• The first external sign of putrefaction in a body lying in air is usually a greenish discolouration of the skin over the region of the caecum which lies fairly superficially, and where the contents of the bowel are more fluid and full of bacteria.
  • The superficial veins specially over the roots of the limb, thighs, sides of the abdomen, shoulders, chest and neck are stained greenish-brown or purplish-red depending on the total amount of sulfhemoglobin formation within the affected vessels. This starts in 24 hours, but is prominent in 36 to 48 hours.
  • The earliest internal change is a reddish-brown discolouration of the inner surfaces of the vessels, especially of the aorta. Internally, decomposition proceeds more slowly than the surface.
  • From 18 to 36 hours after death, Gas bubbles accumulate in the tissues, causing a crepitant, sponge-like feeling which soon begins to distend the body.

Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Gautam Biswas-5th edition; pg:162.

questions.text: Flaying is which type of injury?
questions.solution:
Avulsion is a laceration produced by sufficient force (shearing force) delivered at an acute angle to detach (tear off) a portion of a traumatised surface or viscus from its attachments. The shearing and grinding force by a weight, such as a lorry wheel passing over a limb may produce separation of the skin from the underlying tissues (avulsion) over a relatively large area. This is called "flaying".

Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Gautam Biswas-5th edition; pg:213

choices.text: It is a type of homicide
Single large wound is produced with sword
Sudden decrease of intra-abdominal pressure and cardiac return producing the death

questions.text: Which of the following sentences is false regarding 'HARA-KIRI'?
questions.solution:
HARA-KIRI:

  • It is an unusual type of suicide, in which the victim inflicts a single large wound on the abdomen with a short sword, while in a sitting position or falls forward upon a ceremonial sword and pulls out intestines.
  • To produce impalement by falling on to a knife, there should be enough momentum by the victim moving toward the knife and it would need to be fixed firmly in some way.
  • The sudden evisceration of the internal organs causes a sudden decrease of intra-abdominal pressure and cardiac return, producing sudden cardiac collapse.
  • It is also referred as ‘Seppuku’.

Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Gautam Biswas-5th edition; pg:222

questions.text: Which of the following is not a rifled firearm?
questions.solution:
• A musket is a military shoulder arm. It has a long forestock and usually takes a bayonet at the muzzle. It is a smooth bore weapon.
  • Rifle is a firearm with a rifled barrel which is designated to be fired from the shoulder. Rifles, pistols, revolvers, submachine guns and machine guns—all have rifled barrels.

Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Gautam Biswas-5th edition; pg:229.

questions.text: Which of the following findings is not seen in contact shot firearm entry wound?
questions.solution:
• Tattooing of the skin is seen only when the firearm is fired for a certain distance or there is loose contact with skin.
  • In contact firearm entry wound, there is little or no evidence of burning, singeing, blackening and tattooing.

Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Gautam Biswas-5th edition; pg:236-37.

choices.text: Chronological order in which fractures were formed in a case of sequential firing

questions.text: Puppe's rule is important to know
questions.solution:
Puppe's rule: This rule states that when two fracture lines intersect each other, the second fracture line never crosses the first one. It determines the sequence of shots when several bullets have struck the cranium, and is also applicable to the multiple blunt force impact on the skull.

Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Gautam Biswas-5th edition; pg:241.

questions.text: Cephalic Index of an Indian is
questions.solution: Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Gautam Biswas-5th edition; pg:74

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cardinal sign of asphyxia?
questions.solution:
Petechial haemorrhage is caused due to raised venous pressure from impaired venous return resulting in over distention and rupture of venules, especially in lax tissues and not due to hypoxia of the vessel walls.

Congestion occurs due to obstructed venous return and capillo-venous distention.

Oedema occurs due to increased capillary permeability results from a combination of static and hypoxia. In the early stage the transudation is followed by increased lymph drainage and oedema does not develop.

Cyanosis is the bluish colour of the skin, mucous membrane and internal organs. More than 5 gm% of whole blood should be in the form of reduced haemoglobin to produce cyanosis regardless of the total Hb concentration.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Dr K. S. Narayana-34th edition; pg:131-33.

choices.text: Haemorrhagic discoloration of the umbilical area due to intraperitoneal haemorrhage
Haemorrhagic discoloration of the left flank due to acute haemorrhagic pancreatitis
Haemorrhagic discoloration over mastoid region due to middle cranial fossa fracture
Haemorrhagic discoloration over periorbital region due to injury to forehead

questions.text: Cullen's sign is
questions.solution:
• Cullen's sign is a haemorrhagic discoloration of the umbilical area due to intraperitoneal haemorrhage from any cause.
  • Grey Turner sign is a discoloration of the left flank associated with acute haemorrhagic pancreatitis.
  • Battle's Sign is a haemorrhagic discoloration over the mastoid region due to middle cranial fossa fracture.
  • Raccoon eye sign is a haemorrhagic discoloration over periorbital region due to injury to forehead.

Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Gautam Biswas-5th edition; pg:209-10.

choices.text: Fine bubbles which do not collapse on knife point
Reappears on compression of chest and projects as mushroom like mass from mouth and nostrils

questions.text: Which of the following is not the characteristic of froth in drowning?
questions.solution:
The froth in drowning:

  • A fine, white, lathery froth or foam is seen at the mouth and nostrils, which is one of the most characteristic external signs of drowning.
  • The inhalation of water irritates the mucous membrane of the air-passages due to which the tracheal and bronchial glands secrete large quantities of tenacious mucus, and the alveolar lining cell irritation produces oedema fluid.
  • Vigorous agitation of the seromucoid secretion and the surfactant with aspirated water and retained air, by the violent respiratory efforts, converts the mixture of endogenous secretions and drowning medium into froth.
  • The froth consists of protein and water and the fine bubbles do not readily collapse when touched with the point of a knife due to the presence of surfactant.
  • Froth is more common in drowning in sea water.
  • Froth is usually white, but may be blood-stained, because of slight admixture with blood from intrapulmonary bleeding.
  • If wiped away, it gradually reappears, especially if pressure is applied on the chest.
  • Froth is seen in death due to strangulation, acute pulmonary oedema, electrical shock, during an epileptic fit, in opium poisoning and putrefaction, but in all these cases it is not of such a large quantity as in drowning, and the bubbles are also much larger.
  • Froth formation in the respiratory tract suggests pulmonary oedema.
  • Putrefaction converts froth into bubbly, reddish, foul-smelling fluid.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Dr K. S. Narayana-34th edition; pg:344.

questions.text: All of the following poisons are cerebral stimulants except
questions.solution:
Tricyclic antidepressants are classified under Psychotropic drugs (Mind altering drugs) according to Indian Society of Toxicology's Classification of poisons. They are not cerebral stimulants.

Amphetamine, cocaine and caffeine are CNS stimulants.

Reference - Indian Society of Toxicology's Classification of poison

questions.text: Which of the following poisons have a fruity smell?
questions.solution: Reference : Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology - Gautam Biswas 5th e, Pg. 521

choices.text: Length of tube measured between the nose to earlobe and from there upto 5 cm below the tip of xiphoid process
Length of tube measured between the upper lip to earlobe and from there upto 5 cm below the tip of xiphoid process
Length of tube measured between the lower lip to earlobe and from there upto 5 cm below the tip of xiphoid process
Length of tube measure between the lateral canthus of eye to earlobe and from there upto 5 cm below the tip of xiphoid process

questions.text: A 28-year-old male patient presented in an unconscious condition with pinpoint pupils, profuse perspiration and clothes soiled with vomit at PHC. The medical officer suspects poisoning. He wants to perform gastric lavage. He has Ryle's tube available at the centre. According to the anatomical landmarks, what is the length of tube he should pass for successful insertion of stomach tube?
questions.solution:
The end of the stomach tube is lubricated with liquid paraffin or glycerine and is passed into the stomach by depressing the tongue depressor, and slowly passing it into the stomach, till the 50 cm. mark is reached.

If there are no marks on the tube, the tube should be passed for a distance equal to that measured between the nose to earlobe and from there upto 5 cm below the tip of xiphoid process.

Reference : Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology - Gautam Biswas 5th e, Pg. 516, https://geekymedics.com/nasogastric-ng-tube-insertion/

choices.text: Sample of gastric content to be collected by aspiration after passing the plain water through stomach tube
Sample of gastric content to be collected by aspiration during gastric lavage by potassium permanganate solution
Sample of gastric content to be collected by aspiration after completion of gastric lavage by potassium permanganate solution
Sample of vomitus to be collected after inducing vomiting

questions.text: A 19-year-old female working in fields presented in the emergency department with nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea and pinpoint pupils. She was breathless. The relatives gave the history of ingestion of unknown compound. The medical officer suspected this to be a case of organophosphorus compound poisoning. Which of the following steps is recommended for collection of samples for chemical analysis by the Forensic Science Laboratory?
questions.solution:
The gastric contents are first aspirated by a 50 ml syringe after passing the water through the stomach tube. The gastric contents are preserved in a glass bottle, labelled, sealed and handed over to the police personnel for chemical analysis at FSL

The gastric lavage procedure with potassium permanganate will oxidise the poison. Hence collection of gastric content is done before gastric lavage with potassium permanganate.

Vomiting cannot be induced in every case and conditions. Hence sample is collected routinely after insertion of stomach tube.

Reference : Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology - Gautam Biswas 5th e, Pg. 516

choices.text: Open laparotomy for detection and removal of radiolucent foreign body
Gastric lavage with potassium permanganate solution
Diet containing banana and consult doctor if there are any signs of distress

questions.text: A 5-year-old male child is brought to the emergency department in the evening with history (given by parents) of ingestion of marble of approximately 0.5 cm diameter. The child was asymptomatic and playful. The X Ray of the abdomen did not show the presence of any foreign body. What was the treatment advice by the medical officer?
questions.solution:
Marble is a type of mechanical poison. The treatment for this type of poison is bulky food.

Most of the poisoning in children is by small material like marbles, wheels of small cars, coins etc. which are excreted in faeces.

However, if the foreign body causes intestinal obstruction, admission to hospital and surgical management can be advised. Oil, ghee, banana etc. can be given to child for smooth passage in the faeces.

Gastric lavage has no role in this case.

Vomiting should not be induced in children where the diagnosis is uncertain.

Reference : Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology - Gautam Biswas 5th e, Pg. 518,

Personal communication, Associate Professor, Department of Paediatrics

questions.text: Which of the following ratios is correct when there is equilibrium between blood and urine alcohol concentration?
questions.solution:
Equilibrium between blood and different body fluids/compartments is attained at levels denoted by ratio as below:

  • Blood : Urine = 1:1.33
  • Blood : Saliva = 1:12
  • Blood : CSF = 1:1.17
  • Blood : Exhaled air (breath) = 1:2300

Reference : Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology - Gautam Biswas 5th e, Pg. 597

questions.text: McEwan's sign is present in person who have consumed alcohol. What is the level of blood alcohol concentration at which McEwan's sign can be seen?
questions.solution:
McEwan's sign is seen at blood alcohol concentration of more than 250 mg%.

  • The pupils are constricted but stimulation of the person by pinching or slapping causes dilatation of pupils with slow return.
  • The patient slowly passes into a coma with stertorous breathing at or above this level.

Reference : Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology - Gautam Biswas 5th e, Pg. 598-99

choices.text: Gastric lavage and emesis are contraindicated
Most common accidental poisoning due to hydrocarbons in adults
Aspiration pneumonitis is the most common complication

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding kerosene oil poisoning?
questions.solution:
Kerosene oil poisoning is the most common accidental poisoning in children amongst hydrocarbons. The death is due to respiratory failure.

Reference : Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology - Gautam Biswas 5th e, Pg. 702-03

choices.text: Metabolized in liver to alpha-naphthol, Beta-naphthol and their quinines
Milk and fatty meals are treatment of choice
Accidental poisoning in children can occur mistaking it for candy

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding Naphthalene (mothballs) poisoning?
questions.solution:
Milk and fatty meals are avoided as they facilitate absorption.

Naphthalene (mothballs) poisoning -

Mechanism of action:

  • It causes hemolysis with subsequent blocking of renal tubules and hepatic necrosis.
  • Patients with hereditary deficiency of G6PD in the red cells are more susceptible to hemolysis.

Absorption and metabolism:

  • Toxic effects follow from its absorption from the skin, respiratory tract and GIT.
  • It is metabolized in the liver to α-naphthol, β-naphthol and their quinines.

Treatment:

  • The stomach should be washed out with warm water or saline.
  • Ipecac syrup induced emesis is indicated, followed by activated charcoal.
  • Milk and fatty meals should be avoided as they facilitate absorption.
  • Bowels should be cleared by magnesium sulphate.
  • Sodium bicarbonate should be administered to maintain an alkaline urine so as to prevent the precipitation of acid hematin crystals and blocking of the renal tubules.
  • If cyanosis is present, methemoglobin is suspected and treated with methylene blue.
  • Blood transfusion may be necessary.
  • Hydrocortisone is helpful in limiting naphthalene hemolysis.

Reference : Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology - Gautam Biswas 5th e, Pg. 701-02

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is/are true regarding Hydrogen Sulphide poisoning?
1. It has smell of rotten eggs
2. It is also called knock-down gas
3. Amyl nitrite and sodium nitrite are treatment of choice
4. Avoid 100% oxygenation to detach Hydrogen sulphide from cytochrome oxidase
5. Asphyxial signs are rare
questions.solution:
Hydrogen sulphide poisoning:

  • It has smell of rotten eggs.
  • It is also called knock-down gas.
  • Amyl nitrite and sodium nitrite are treatment of choice.
  • 100% oxygenation has to be done during treatment.
  • Asphyxial signs like cyanosis, frothing at mouth and nose and petechial haemorrhages are seen as it interferes with cytochrome oxidase.

Reference : Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology - Gautam Biswas 5th e, Pg. 688-89

questions.text: A 21-year-old female was brought to the casualty in unconscious condition after attending a rave party. She was confused, ataxic and dizzy. Police gave a history of seizure of multiple bottles of Rohypnol. What is the antidote of choice?
questions.solution:
Flunitrazepam or Rohypnol is a benzodiazepine. Flumazenil selectively blocks the central effects of benzodiazepines by competitive inhibition. Rohypnol is a date rape drug.

Fomepizole is antidote for alcohol.

Fluoxetine is SSRI (selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor) for treatment of depression, OCD, panic disorders etc.

Fexofenadine is antihistamine

Reference : Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology - Gautam Biswas 5th e, Pg. 670-71

questions.text: Reye's syndrome is seen in
questions.solution:
Reye's syndrome is characterised by acute onset of hepatic failure and encephalopathy with residual neuronal manifestation. It may develop in children <15 years on intake of aspirin.

Reference : Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology - Gautam Biswas 5th e, Pg. 671

questions.text: What is the specific antidote for treatment of paracetamol poisoning?
questions.solution:
• N - Acetylcysteine is the specific antidote used in treatment of paracetamol
  • DMPS and BAL are used in treatment of poisoning by heavy metal.
  • Atropine is a specific antidote for organophosphorus and carbamate

Reference : Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology - Gautam Biswas 5th e, Pg. 667

choices.text: i, iii and iv are correct

questions.text:
Some statements regarding alphos poisoning are given below. Choose the correct response which depicts the characteristics of alphos poisoning.
i. There is no antidote for alphos poisoning
ii. Cause of death is acute renal failure and respiratory acidosis
iii. Fatal dose is 500 mg
iv. It has kerosene like smell
questions.solution:
Alphos is aluminium phosphide.

  • There is no antidote for alphos poisoning.
  • It is a protoplasmic poison. It inhibits mitochondrial respiration and Kreb's cycle leading to anaerobic respiration and production of lactic acid thereby producing metabolic acidosis.
  • The cause of death is metabolic acidosis and renal failure.
  • The fatal dose is 5 grams (1 -3 tablets).
  • It has a garlic-like smell.

Reference : Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology - Gautam Biswas 5th e, Pg. 660-65

questions.text:
A 19-year-old male was brought to casualty after ingestion of some unknown compound in the fields. On examination, conjunctiva was congested, and the patient was in respiratory distress with hemoptysis. Urine output was scanty. The tongue picture is as depicted in the image below:

What is the probable cause of poisoning?
questions.solution:
Features of paraquat poisoning -

  • Ulceration and corrosion of mouth and tongue (paraquat tongue).
  • Irritation and inflammation of skin, cornea, conjunctiva and nasal mucosa.
  • Cough, hemoptysis, dyspnea due to pulmonary edema, aphonia and aspiration.
  • There is oliguria and renal failure.

Reference : Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology - Gautam Biswas 5th e, Pg. 658-59

questions.text: A 21-year-old male was brought to casualty with a history of ingestion of unknown compound in the farm. A provisional diagnosis of organophosphorus compound poisoning was made after examination of the patient. What is the specific antidote that can be administered at the earliest?
questions.solution:
Atropine is the specific antidote for organophosphorus compound poisoning.

Specific cholinesterase reactivators like diacetyl monoxime (DAM), or pralidoxime (PAM) act by competing for the phosphate moiety of the organophosphorus compound and release it from the cholinesterase enzyme. They are used in conjunction with atropine.

Physostigmine will increase the effect of poisoning.

Reference : Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology - Gautam Biswas 5th e, Pg. 652-56

choices.text: Only ii, iii & iv are correct

questions.text:
A 21-year-old male was brought to casualty with a history of ingestion of unknown compound in the farm. A provisional diagnosis of organophosphorus compound poisoning was made after examination of the patient. What is the specific antidote that can be administered at the earliest?Choose the correct response regarding tear gas.
i. Chemical compounds to permanently incapacitate the function by causing irritation of eyes, mouth, throat, lungs and skin.
ii. CN (chloroacetophenone), CS (chlorobenzylidene malononitrile) and OC (oleoresin capsicum) or pepper spray are commonly used as tear gases.
iii. Very low concentration (0.003 mg/m3) can cause ocular irritation.
iv. These agents are used for riot control and crowd suppression.
questions.solution:
Tear gas -

  • CN (chloroacetophenone), CS (chlorobenzylidene malononitrile) and OC (oleoresin capsicum) or pepper spray are commonly used as tear gases.
  • Very low concentration (0.003 mg/m3) can cause ocular irritation.
  • These agents are used for riot control and crowd suppression.
  • Chemical compounds to TEMPORARILY incapacitate the function by causing irritation of eyes, mouth, throat, lungs and skin.
  • These agents cause significant lacrimation and rhinorrhoea due to irritation and hence called tear gases.

Reference : Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology - Gautam Biswas 5th e, Pg. 648

questions.text:
A 24-year-old working in a garage was brought to the emergency department in unconscious condition. His pulse was thready, hypotensive with irregular respirations. Ophthalmoscopic examination showed flame shaped retinal hemorrhages and bright red retinal veins. Bullous lesions are present on the body. What of the following statement/s is/are correct regarding further management of the patient?
1.Send blood for COHb estimation
2. Start oxygen therapy with 100% oxygen by tight fitting high flow reservoir face mark or endotracheal tube
3. Diazepam to alleviate anxiety
4.Amyl nitrite by i.v. infusion
questions.solution:
The provisional diagnosis of carbon monoxide poisoning can be confirmed by COHb estimation and treatment with 100% oxygen for 4 to 6 hours will show improvement due to dissociation of carbon monoxide from haemoglobin.

Patient is unconscious hence diazepam has no role.

There is no role of amyl nitrite as it is not the case of cyanide poisoning.

Reference : Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology - Gautam Biswas 5th e, Pg. 645-47

questions.text: Identify the plant
questions.solution:
• Nerium odorum is yellow or white flowers with globular fruits light green in colour containing seeds.
  • Aconite is a root.
  • Nicotiana tobacum do not have yellow flowers.
  • Datura is white or purple.

Reference : Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology - Gautam Biswas 5th e, Pg. 636-97

questions.text: 20-minute whole blood clotting time is an important diagnostic test used in bite by which snake?
questions.solution:
• Viper snake venom is vasculotoxic which increases the clotting time for which 20-minute whole blood clotting time is done for diagnosis.
  • Common krait and cobra venom are neurotoxic.
  • Sea snake venom is myotoxic.

Reference : Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology - Gautam Biswas 5th e, Pg. 582

choices.text: Erosion and haemorrhages in oesophagus and stomach

questions.text: Which autopsy feature/s will not be seen during the autopsy of a person who died due to cyanide poisoning?
questions.solution:
• There will be a bitter almond smell in cyanide poisoning.
  • The organs will be congested and erosions and haemorrhages in oesophagus and stomach.
  • The lividity will be bright pink in colour.

Reference : Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology - Gautam Biswas 5th e, Pg. 642

questions.text: A 22-year-old black male was brought to the emergency room in semi-conscious condition. He had a past history of addiction presented multiple times with tactile hallucinations. He had black coloured stained teeth and tongue. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient presented with tactile hallucinations multiple times which is known as Magnan’s symptoms occurring in cocaine poisoning.

Reference : Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology - Gautam Biswas 5th e, Pg. 627-28

questions.text: Which of the following is an active principle of ganja?
questions.solution:
• Cannabinols are active principles in cannabis sativa. Ganja, charas, hashish oil, bhang are made from cannabis sativa which generate tetrahydrocannabinol on activation resulting in harmful effects on the body.
  • Methamphetamine is a metabolic product of amphetamine.
  • Crotin is the active principle of Croton tiglium.
  • N-acetyl cysteine is an antidote for paracetamol

Reference : Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology - Gautam Biswas 5th e, Pg. 620

questions.text: Which of the following does not penetrate CNS and produce toxicity?
questions.solution:
Propoxur is a carbamate. Symptoms of toxicity begin in 15 minutes to 2 hours.

Carbamates differ toxicologically from organophosphates:

  • They will spontaneously hydrolyse from the cholinesterase enzymatic site within 24 to 48 hours, whereas organophosphates will not.
  • They do not effectively penetrate into the CNS, and as such CNS toxicity is limited.

All other clinical manifestations are similar to organophosphates.

Malathion, parathion and finit are organophosphorus compounds.

Reference : Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology - Gautam Biswas 5th e, Pg. 652

The essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology - Dr KSN Narayan Reddy 34th e, Pg. 488

questions.text: Red velvety stomach mucosa is present in
questions.solution:
Red velvety mucosa is seen in acute arsenic poisoning.

Reference : Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology - Gautam Biswas 5th e, Pg. 536

questions.text: An apparently healthy girl was brought to the emergency department with sudden onset of nausea, vomiting, ptosis, abdominal pain and quadriplegia. She was sleeping on the floor during the rainy season. The provisional diagnosis is
questions.solution:
The signs and symptoms are suggestive of neurotoxic snake bite.

Neurotoxins are found in elapid, hydrophid, vipirid and cortalid venoms. They are neuromuscular non-depolarising blocking agents, which produce a curare-like effect and paralysis, especially of respiratory centre.

Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS) is a rare disorder where the body's immune system damages nerve. The damage to the nerves causes muscle weakness and sometimes paralysis. While its cause is not fully understood, the syndrome often follows infection with a virus or bacteria.

Poliomyelitis has flu-like symptoms and some people develop symptoms of meningitis or paralysis gradually.

There is no history of ingestion of any substance which can lead to poisoning.

Reference : Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology - Gautam Biswas 5th e, Pg. 581

questions.text: In which type of delusion, the person believes that he is referred to by all agencies, media and persons?
questions.solution:
Delusion is a false belief in something which is not a fact, and which persists even after its falsity has been clearly demonstrated.

Types of delusion:

  • Grandeur or exaltation : A man Imagines himself to be very rich while in reality he is a pauper. They are seen in delirium tremens.
  • Persecution (paranoid) : The person has irrational fears that others intend to harm them. They are seen in paranoid schizophrenia, dementia and depression.
  • Reference: The person believes that people, things, events, etc., refer to him in a special way. He believes that even strangers in the street are looking at him d are talking about him, or items in the radio or newspapers are referring to him.
  • Influence : They occur in schizophrenia. The person complains that his thoughts, feelings and actions are being influenced and controlled by some outside agency, like radio, hypnotism, telepathy, etc.
  • Infidelity : The man imagines his wife to be unfaithful while in act she is chaste.
  • Self-reproach : The person blames himself for the past failures and misdeeds which are often of no importance.
  • Nihilistic : the person declares that he does not exist or that there is no world, etc.
  • Hypochondriacal: The person believes that there is something wrong with his body, though he is healthy.
  • Other types are of jealousy, of religion, etc.

Reference : Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology - Gautam Biswas 5th e, Pg. 443
